00040 #ifndef _soundmanager_h
00041 #define _soundmanager_h
00042 
00043 #include "crossplatformexport.h"
00044 #include "datatypes.h"
00045 #include "managerbase.h"
00046 #include "sound.h"
00047 #include "soundlistener.h"
00048 
00049 #include <vector>
00050 #include <map>
00051 #include <sstream>
00052 
00053 namespace cAudio
00054 {
00055     class IAudioManager;
00056     class IAudioSource;
00057     class IListener;
00058 }
00059 
00060 namespace phys
00061 {
00062     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00063     /// @class SoundManager
00064     /// @headerfile soundmanager.h
00065     /// @brief This is simply a place for storing all the Sound utilities and functions.
00066     /// @details This is a place for loading, storing, and running sound files as
00067     /// necessary in a given game.
00068     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00069     class PHYS_LIB SoundManager : public ManagerBase
00070     {
00071         protected:
00072             cAudio::IAudioManager* AudioManager;
00073             std::map< String, SoundSet* > SoundSets;
00074             cAudio::IListener* AudioListener;
00075 
00076         public:
00077             /// @brief Class Constructor
00078             /// @details This is the class constructor.  It gives you the option to start up the manager
00079             /// with default values if you choose.  If not then you'll need to setup and initialize the
00080             /// manager yourself after it is constructed.
00081             /// @param DefaultSettings Whether or not to load default settings and initialize the
00082             /// manager immediately.
00083             SoundManager(bool DefaultSettings=true);
00084             /// @brief Class Destructor
00085             /// @details The class destructor.
00086             ~SoundManager();
00087             /// @brief Inherited Initializer.
00088             /// @details Written to allow the class to compile, this currently does nothing, but could be used to run code Use InitializeManager() instead.
00089             void Initialize();
00090             /// @brief Empty MainLoopItems
00091             /// @details This class implements this for the sake of entension and compatibility this function does nothing
00092             virtual void DoMainLoopItems();
00093 
00094             /// @brief Initializes the Manager.
00095             /// @details This function will initialize the manager using the device and parameters provided.
00096             /// You need to call this function if you passed false into the sound manager constructor before
00097             /// you can use the manager.
00098             /// @param DeviceName The name of the device you wish to have this manager interface with/use.
00099             /// @param OutputFrequency Frequency of the output audio, -1 for the devices default.
00100             /// @param EAXEffectSlots The number of effects per sound allowed to be applied.
00101             void InitializeManager(ConstString &DeviceName, int OutputFrequency=-1, int EAXEffectSlots=4);
00102             /// @brief Creates a sound instance from a file that can be used to play sounds.
00103             /// @details This function will create a Sound from a file and returns a pointer to that Sound.
00104             /// You can also specify if you want the sound to be streamed from the disk so that it doesn't
00105             /// have to load the entire song from disk first.
00106             /// @param SoundName The name of the Sound instance.
00107             /// @param FilePath The path to the file AND the name of the file.
00108             /// @param Stream Whether or not to stream the audio from the disk.  Otherwise it has be completely
00109             /// loaded into memory before it can be used.
00110             /// @return Returns a pointer to the Sound Instance that was created.
00111             Sound* CreateSound(ConstString &SoundName, ConstString &FilePath, bool Stream);
00112             /// @brief Creates a sound instance from a memory buffer.
00113             /// @details This function allows you to create a sound instance from a sound that is already loaded
00114             /// into memory.
00115             /// @param SoundName The name of the sound instance.
00116             /// @param Data Pointer to the char array (buffer).
00117             /// @param Size Size of the char array (buffer).
00118             /// @param Extension The extension of the file used to load that sound (wav, ogg).
00119             /// @return Returns a pointer to the Sound Instance that was created.
00120             Sound* CreateSoundFromMemory(String &SoundName, const char* Data, int Size, String &Extension);
00121             /*/// @brief Creates a sound instance from raw data in a buffer(unknown format).
00122             /// @details This function allows you to create a sound instance from raw data of an unknown format existing
00123             /// inside memory.  This will assemble a decoder for the data based on the information you provide.
00124             /// @param SoundName The name of the sound instance.
00125             /// @param Data Pointer to the char array (buffer).
00126             /// @param Size Size of the char array (buffer).
00127             /// @param Frequency The Sample rate of the audio data.
00128             /// @param Quality The format of the sound.  Options are: 1 for 8bit Mono, 2 for 8bit Stereo, 3 for 16bit Mono, or 4 for 16bit Stereo.
00129             Sound* CreateSoundFromRaw(String &SoundName, const char* Data, int Size, Whole Frequency, Whole Quality);*/
00130             /// @brief Deletes a Sound.
00131             /// @details Deletes a single Sound via a pointer.
00132             /// @param SoundName A pointer to the Sound you want deleted.
00133             void DestroySound(Sound* SoundName);
00134             /// @brief Gets a sound by it's name.
00135             /// @details This function will find and return the sound with the speicified name.
00136             /// @return Returns a pointer to the specified sound.
00137             Sound* GetSoundByName(String SoundName);
00138             /// @brief Deletes all stored sounds.
00139             /// @details This function will delete every Sound that is stored in the manager.
00140             void DestroyAllSounds();
00141             /// @brief Creates a sound set.
00142             /// @details This function will create a sound set vector you can use to store similiar sound instances.
00143             /// @param SoundSetName The name you wish the sound set to have.
00144             /// @return Returns a pointer to the created Vector.
00145             SoundSet* CreateSoundSet(String SoundSetName);
00146             /// @brief Gets an existing sound set.
00147             /// @details This function will find the specified sound set and return a pointer to it.
00148             /// @param SoundSetName The name of the sound set to retrieve.
00149             /// @return Returns a pointer to the named Vector.
00150             SoundSet* GetSoundSet(String SoundSetName);
00151             /// @brief Add's a sound to the defined set.
00152             /// @details This function will add a sound instance to a created sound set.
00153             /// @param SoundName The sound instance to be added.
00154             void AddSoundToSoundSet(String SoundSetName, Sound* SoundInst);
00155             /// @brief Gets the name of an available device.
00156             /// @details This function will retrieve the name of a device by it's index on the sound managers device list.
00157             /// @param Index The position on the device list you wish to access the name of.
00158             /// @return Returns the name of the device.
00159             String GetAvailableDeviceNameByIndex(Whole Index);
00160             /// @brief Gets the name of the default device.
00161             /// @details This function will return the name of the system default device.
00162             /// @return Returns the name of the default device.
00163             String GetDefaultDeviceName();
00164             /// @brief Gets the number of available devices.
00165             /// @details This function will return the total number of available devices, including the default.
00166             /// @return Returns the number of available devices.
00167             Whole GetAvailableDeviceCount();
00168             /// @brief Retrieve's the listener for this sound manager.
00169             /// @details This function will return the listener for this manager which can be used to help create 3D sound.
00170             /// @return Returns a pointer to the managers Sound Listener.
00171             SoundListener* GetListener();
00172             /// @brief Gets the manager type.
00173             /// @details Gets the type of manager that this is.
00174             /// @return Returns the manager type.
00175             ManagerTypeName GetType() const;
00176 
00177             /// @brief This gets the logs that the audio subystem creates
00178             /// @details Internally the Physgame engine currently uses cAudio to process 3d sound. It has it's own
00179             /// logging system that we have customized to work with our logger.
00180             /// @return This gets the log of what actions the audio system has performed
00181             std::stringstream* GetLogs();
00182 
00183             /// @brief This empties logs that the audio subystem creates
00184             /// @details Internally the Physgame engine currently uses cAudio to process 3d sound. It has it's own
00185             /// logging system that we have customized to work with our logger. This clears that data allow us to
00186             /// work with it as we need
00187             void ClearLogs();
00188     };
00189 }
00190 
00191 #endif
